text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

17.1	The United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN-Women) is responsible for supporting the achievement of gender equality and the fulfilment of the rights and empowerment of all women and girls as actors and beneficiaries of sustainable development, human rights, humanitarian action and peace and security. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly, Economic and Social Council and Security Council resolutions, including General Assembly resolutions 64/289, in which the Assembly established UN-Women as a composite entity that functions as a secretariat, carries out operational activities at the country and regional levels, and leads, coordinates and promotes the accountability of the United Nations system in its work on gender equality and the empowerment of women; 70/1 on the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, pursuant to which UN-Women supports systematic mainstreaming of a gender perspective in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda; 72/279 on the repositioning of the United Nations development system; and 79/226 on the quadrennial comprehensive policy review of operational activities for development of the United Nations system, in which the Assembly reiterated its call upon the United Nations development system to enhance and accelerate gender mainstreaming through the full implementation of the System-wide Action Plan on Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women, developed under the leadership of UN-Women, as well as the United Nations country team performance indicators for gender equality and the empowerment of women (the UNCT SWAP “scorecard”), in particular with regard to gender-responsive performance management and strategic planning.

17.2	The mandate of UN-Women endows it with a unique role and capacity to: (a) support the strengthening and development of global norms and standards, including with country-level experiences; (b) promote more effective coordination, coherence and gender mainstreaming across the United Nations system in support of commitments for gender equality and the empowerment of women; and (c) support Member States, upon request, to translate global norms and standards into legislation, policies and development plans as part of its operational activities. UN-Women also has a critical role in supporting the mobilization of civil society, the private sector and other relevant stakeholders, at all levels, in support of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and the gender-responsive implementation of the 2030 Agenda. UN-Women will continue to support Member States’ commitment to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls as a crucial contribution to progress across all the Sustainable Development Goals, as reiterated in the Pact for the Future.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

17.3	The UN-Women strategic plan 2026–2029 will guide the Entity’s activities and its strategic direction, objectives and approaches to support the efforts of Member States towards the achievement of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls and the realization of their human rights.

17.4	The strategic plan will be based on an extensive consultative process and draw from analysis of progress and persistent challenges, including recommendations from the 30-year review and appraisal of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, the review of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals, particularly related to gender equality and the rights and empowerment of women and girls, the gender equality commitments in the Pact for the Future, and lessons learned from the midterm review of the UN-Women strategic plan 2022–2025.

17.5	In 2026, UN-Women will continue its work on its established thematic impact areas: (a) governance and participation in public life; (b) women’s economic empowerment; (c) ending violence against women and girls; and (d) women and peace and security, humanitarian action and disaster risk reduction. Given the interconnected nature of global challenges, UN-Women will continue to focus on integrated approaches to address the root causes of gender inequality and discrimination against women and girls and effect broader systems change by advancing seven systemic outcomes across the four thematic impact areas: (a) the strengthening of global normative frameworks and gender-responsive laws, policies and institutions; (b) financing for gender equality; (c) positive social norms, including by engaging men and boys; (d) equitable access by women to services, goods and resources; (e) women’s voices, leadership and agency; (f) the production, analysis and use of gender statistics, sex-disaggregated data, and knowledge; and (g) United Nations system coordination for gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls.

17.6	UN-Women will continue to implement its programme by leveraging its normative support function, United Nations system coordination role and operational activities in an integrated and mutually reinforcing manner for transformative results.

17.7	UN-Women will continue to act as a knowledge hub to support gender mainstreaming and provide research and data analysis to inform policies, strategies and other interventions, and substantive and technical support and expertise to requesting Member States. It will continue to facilitate the mainstreaming of a gender perspective into intergovernmental norms and standards. It will also provide support to Member States, upon request, in implementing commitments to gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls through operational activities. UN-Women will continue to work in partnership with a range of actors and support, at the request of Member States, civil society, the private sector and other relevant stakeholders, for accelerated action for gender equality and the rights and empowerment of women and girls.

17.8	UN-Women will continue to place business transformation at the heart of its organizational effectiveness and efficiency framework, including by strengthening capabilities in innovation, digital transformation and strategic foresight, in line with paragraph 73 (a) of the Pact for the Future, under action 45, and will enhance its culture of accountability and strengthening organizational performance management through a cascading internal management system.

17.9	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, UN-Women will continue to leverage its mandate to further enhance country, regional and global efforts of the United Nations system towards gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls, including through the repositioned United Nations development system for integrated, cost-effective support to partners. UN-Women will continue to promote accountability for gender equality through support for the implementation of frameworks such as the United Nations System-wide Action Plan on Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women and the United Nations country team System-wide Action Plan “scorecard” and their recommendations at the country level. UN-Women will continue to build strategic partnerships with United Nations entities to deliver coordinated and coherent results for women and girls across the development, peace and security and humanitarian contexts. Further, the Entity will collaborate with other United Nations entities, including through the Inter-Agency and Expert Group on Sustainable Development Goal Indicators, providing a gender perspective on methodology development, monitoring and follow-up, as well as capacity development. UN-Women will also collaborate with departments and offices of the United Nations Secretariat, including on issues related to women and peace and security, sexual violence in conflict, gender mainstreaming in peacekeeping operations and gender parity. UN-Women will continue its cooperation with and support to the Security Council, the Peacebuilding Commission and the Human Rights Council, as requested. UN-Women will continue to brief the Security Council, upon request, and provide secretariat services to the Council’s Informal Expert Group on Women and Peace and Security.

17.10	Where it has a presence, UN-Women will support the integration of a gender perspective in United Nations country team programming processes, including the common country assessments and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, joint initiatives, collective advocacy and coordination to ensure a coherent system-wide approach in operational activities. Where a humanitarian response is in place, UN-Women will support the integration of a gender perspective into the planning and implementation of the humanitarian response. UN-Women will continue to chair or co-chair the gender theme groups of United Nations country teams.
17.11	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	The continued availability of voluntary contributions, which account for approximately 98 per cent of the resources of UN-Women;
(b)	The commitment of Member States to advance gender equality and the rights and empowerment of all women and girls, including by achieving consensus in relevant intergovernmental meetings;

(c)	The commitment of Member States to adopt and implement laws, policies and strategies, allocate adequate resources, and create and maintain an enabling environment for civil society and women’s organizations in their work for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls.

17.12	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy and the UN-Women global strategy on the empowerment of women and girls with disabilities, UN-Women, together with other United Nations entities, will accelerate the effective mainstreaming of disability inclusion and promote accessibility in its institutional processes, collaboration and programming, in partnership with Member States, organizations of persons with disabilities and other partners. UN-Women will continue to chair the United Nations Inter-agency Group on Gender Equality and Disability Inclusion. Where it has a presence, UN-Women will facilitate an intersectional approach to disability inclusion by leveraging the United Nations country team presence and operational and programming processes.
Legislative mandates
17.13	The list below, which was reviewed in the preparation of the proposed programme budget, provides all mandates entrusted to UN-Women.
General Assembly resolutions

children.text: Evaluation activities
17.15	The following evaluations conducted by the UN-Women Independent Evaluation Service and completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Corporate Thematic Evaluation of UN-Women’s Support to Women’s Political Participation: Insights from the Field;

(b)	Are We Getting There? A Synthesis of United Nations System Evaluations of Sustainable Development Goal 5, and its companion report, Getting There Together: A Synthesis of Inter-Agency Programme Evaluations on Sustainable Development Goal 5.

17.16	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, UN-Women refined its programmatic approach, notably on women’s political participation, to incorporate key recommendations, such as multi-stakeholder, multi-year designs to achieve sustainable change and address barriers to women’s political participation. Evidence from nearly 300 evaluations informed the Sustainable Development Goal 5 syntheses, highlighting the effectiveness of integrated programming and the importance of data, advocacy and civil society partnerships.
17.17	An evaluation of the effectiveness of the role of UN-Women in advancing one of the seven systemic outcomes is being planned for 2026.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Intergovernmental support, coordination and strategic partnerships
Objective

17.18	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the achievement of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, including full enjoyment of their human rights.
Strategy
17.19	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support the normative processes of intergovernmental bodies, including the Commission on the Status of Women, by facilitating the exchange of good practices and lessons learned among Governments and other relevant stakeholders, including through meetings, the issuance of reports and the presentation of analyses and policy options that enable discussion on key gender equality issues;

(b)	Lead, coordinate and promote the accountability of the United Nations system for gender equality and the empowerment of women, and gender mainstreaming. This includes providing expertise, advocacy, monitoring of the development of relevant tools and guidance and capacity-building within the United Nations system. Actions towards system-wide improvement of the status of women will also be undertaken;

(c)	Develop strategic partnerships by enabling civil society actors and other stakeholders to contribute to relevant intergovernmental processes, including through information dissemination, the convening of stakeholders to share lessons learned and recommendations for actions and the provision of funding for attending capacity- and alliance-building opportunities.

17.20	In doing so, the subprogramme will assist Member States in their efforts to accelerate the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, achieve Sustainable Development Goal 5 and systematically mainstream a gender perspective into the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
17.21	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A strengthened global normative framework and increased reflection of a gender perspective in the outcomes of intergovernmental processes;

(b)	An enabling working environment to accelerate gender mainstreaming and progress towards gender parity goals in the United Nations system, leading to greater achievement of results towards gender equality;

(c)	Enhanced cooperation among stakeholders and Governments on gender equality and the empowerment of women, as well as enhanced opportunities for stakeholders to present lessons learned and good practices in conjunction with intergovernmental processes, and the availability of a growing resource base.
Programme performance in 2024
Civil society and young women and girls have effective channels to shape the implementation of the Beijing Platform for Action to reflect their needs

17.22	The contribution of civil society, including young women and girls, to the implementation of the Beijing Platform for Action is crucial. The subprogramme engaged civil society in the 30-year review and appraisal of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. In 2024, the subprogramme supported consultations with civil society, young people and adolescent girls by creating intergenerational common engagement platforms for sharing information and strengthening advocacy capacities. Virtual meetings reached 930 civil society representatives, while regional and national meetings engaged 5,072 young women and girls, creating strategic pathways for young people to influence the regional discussions. The subprogramme facilitated the participation of 570 youth representatives in the review meetings of the regional commissions, ensuring that diverse voices influenced intergovernmental processes.
17.23	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.I).
Figure 17.I

Performance measure: number of civil society and youth representatives participating in consultations and capacity-building workshops on the 30-year review of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: leaving no women or girls with disabilities behind – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

17.24	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 24 organizations of persons with disabilities collaborating and partnering with United Nations country offices to address the specific needs and demands of women and girls with disabilities, which exceeded the planned target of 20 organizations.
17.25	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.II).
Figure 17.II

Performance measure: number of organizations of persons with disabilities partnering with United Nations country offices to address the specific needs and demands of women and girls with disabilities (cumulative)
Result 2: strengthened global norms and standards on gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

17.26	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 94 per cent of recommendations in the report of the Secretary-General on the priority theme of the Commission on the Status of Women being reflected in the agreed conclusions of the Commission at its sixty-eighth session, which exceeded the planned target of 90 per cent.
17.27	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 17.2).
Table 17.2
Performance measure

table_content.text: Member States adopt a political declaration on the occasion of the thirtieth anniversary of the Fourth World Conference on Women

children.text: a	Percentage of recommendations in the report of the Secretary-General on the priority theme of the Commission on the Status of Women that are reflected in the agreed conclusions of the Commission.
Result 3: a gender perspective mainstreamed in United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks – Proposed programme plan for 2026

17.28	The United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework is a critical planning instrument from which the funds and programmes derive their country programme document outcomes. The Framework’s guidance identifies gender equality and women’s empowerment as one of the eight guiding principles. The subprogramme has led an inter-agency initiative to develop training material for United Nations country teams on mainstreaming a gender perspective in the Frameworks.
Lessons learned and planned change

17.29	The lesson for the subprogramme was the critical need to offer ongoing technical support to country teams to sustain institutional knowledge and technical capacity. Specific tools are required to support new cohorts of countries rolling out the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will continue to offer technical support and capacity-building to country teams. It will also develop new country strategic notes, with outcomes aligned with the Frameworks to ensure that a gender perspective is mainstreamed.
17.30	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.III).
Figure 17.III
Performance measure: percentage of new United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks containing a stand-alone outcome on gender equality (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Policy and programme activities
Objective

17.32	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to enhance efforts in the elimination of discrimination against women and girls and the achievement of gender equality in, among other things, the fields of sustainable development, human rights and peace and security, including through enhanced accountability of the United Nations system.
Strategy
17.33	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Serve as a global knowledge centre on gender equality and the empowerment of women, including in the areas of women and peace and security, ending violence against women, the economic empowerment of women, and governance, by undertaking and disseminating research, analysis and evaluation of trends, including on new and emerging issues and their impact on the situation of women;

(b)	Provide advisory, technical and advocacy support, training and capacity development, including through field offices, to Member States, upon request, to advance the implementation of their commitments on gender equality and the empowerment of women, in line with their national priorities;

(c)	Ensure the accountability of the United Nations system, including the United Nations country and regional teams and their thematic groups on gender equality, by offering guidance and through engagement in their work on gender equality and the empowerment of women.

17.34	In doing so, the subprogramme will assist Member States in their efforts to achieve Sustainable Development Goal 5 and to systematically mainstream a gender perspective into the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
17.35	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Policies and actions taken by national and regional bodies to implement United Nations instruments, standards and resolutions that contribute to gender equality and the empowerment of women, focusing on the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, the outcome of the twenty-third special session of the General Assembly and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women;

(b)	Increased capacity of Member States to implement, monitor and evaluate laws, policies and strategies that contribute to the achievement of gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls and the realization of their human rights;

(c)	Improved ability of United Nations programmes to more effectively support Member States, at their request, in the implementation of commitments to eliminate discrimination against women and girls.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened disaster risk reduction policies

17.36	Gender-sensitive disaster risk reduction policies, plans and programmes are crucial to ensure that disaster policies address the unique and differentiated needs of, access to resources by and opportunities for women and men. Recognizing this, UN-Women, through its Women’s Resilience to Disasters programme, expanded global knowledge in 2024 to support the development and implementation of disaster risk reduction policies that reflect these differentiated needs. The Women’s Resilience to Disasters policy tracker identifies good practices that support the resilience of women to disasters across 193 Member States in order to facilitate peer learning and South-South cooperation. To date, the tracker has identified 283 national and regional disaster risk reduction frameworks that support gender equality. During 2024, with the technical support of UN-Women, 30 countries developed gender-sensitive disaster risk reduction legislation, policies, strategies, plans and assessments.
17.37	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.IV).
Figure 17.IV

Performance measure: number of countries that developed gender-sensitive disaster risk reduction legislation, policies, strategies, plans and assessments with the technical support of the Entity (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: governments adopt policies and make investments to transform the care economy – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

17.38	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 1,020 institutions benefiting from the support of UN-Women to improve the provision of essential services, goods and/or resources for women, which exceeded the planned target of 1,014 institutions.
17.39	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.V).
Figure 17.V
Performance measure: number of institutions benefiting from the support of the Entity to improve the provision of essential services, goods and/or resources for women (cumulative)
Result 2: governments implement fiscal policies and gender-responsive budgeting to promote gender equality – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

17.40	The subprogramme’s work contributed to an additional 1,115 partners, including civil society organizations, parliaments and audit institutions, with strengthened capacities to design and implement fiscal policies and gender-responsive budgeting to enable the strengthened tracking, allocation and expenditure of public resources for gender equality, which met the planned target.
17.41	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 17.4).
Table 17.4
Performance measure

children.text: a	See General Assembly resolution 77/181.
Result 3: Governments adopt national action plans to prevent violence against women and girls – Proposed programme plan for 2026

17.42	Violence against women and girls is one of the world’s most prevalent human rights violations, with one in three women worldwide subjected to either physical and/or sexual intimate partner violence or non-partner sexual violence in their lifetime. In recent decades, an increasing number of countries have introduced national action plans to address violence against women and girls and promote gender equality.
Lessons learned and planned change

17.43	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to provide targeted support to Member States on the prevention of violence against women and girls, considering that many policies and strategies focus on responding to violence after it occurs, rather than addressing its root causes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide policy guidance, technical support and capacity strengthening, upon request, to Governments and key stakeholders to formulate national action plans and incorporate prevention into policies.
17.44	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 17.VI).
Figure 17.VI
Performance measure: number of countries that have adopted national action plans to prevent violence against women and girls with the support of the Entity (cumulative)
Deliverables
17.45	Table 17.5 lists all deliverables of the subprogramme.
Table 17.5
Subprogramme 2: deliverables for the period 2024–2026, by category and subcategory

12.	On essential services to respond to violence against women and on integrating gender equality into macroeconomic policies
13.	On the implementation of Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) on women and peace and security and its agenda

Consultation, advice and advocacy: technical advice to requesting Member States and non-governmental organizations on access to financial markets and services for women, gender-responsive budgeting, gender-responsive development plans at the national and local levels, and gender equality policies, strategies and action plans; technical advice to strengthen the role of national women’s machinery in the development, implementation and monitoring of gender equality policies, strategies and action plans; country-level advice and assistance on the implementation of the women and peace and security agenda; consultation on priority themes and issues in preparation for the session of the Commission on the Status of Women; technical advice to requesting ministries of finance, planning and women’s affairs on integrating a gender perspective into policies on macroeconomics, social protection systems, decent work and the care economy, environmental degradation and climate change to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.

Overview

17.47	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in tables 17.9 to 17.11 and figure 17.VII.

17.48	As shown in tables 17.9 (1) and 17.10 (1), the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $11,413,000, reflecting a decrease of $30,400 compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from technical adjustments. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Technical adjustments

17.49	As shown in table 17.9 (1), resource changes reflect a decrease of $30,400, which relates to subprogramme 2, Policy and programme activities. The decrease of $30,400 relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with the request by the General Assembly in its resolution 78/150 that the Secretary-General report to the Assembly at its eightieth session on achieving gender equality and empowering all women and girls for realizing all Sustainable Development Goals; the amount was approved for 2025, but was not allotted, and is not required in 2026.
Extrabudgetary resources

17.50	As reflected in tables 17.9 (2) and 17.10 (2), extrabudgetary resources are estimated at $515,000,000. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 471 posts (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 4 D-2, 20 D-1, 85 P-5, 61 P-4, 49 P-3, 8 P-2/1, 76 National Professional Officer and 167 General Service (Other level)) to mainly provide the functions of support for overall executive direction and management, including the planning, coordination, management and assessment of the programme of work and the strategic plan of UN-Women and the production of the programme’s deliverables. In addition, non-post resources would be used under subprogramme 1 to facilitate engagement with intergovernmental bodies. Under subprogramme 2, resources are expected to support Member States, upon request, in implementing their national commitments to eliminating discrimination against women and girls, empowering women and achieving equality between women and men as partners and beneficiaries of sustainable development, human rights of women and girls, humanitarian action and peace and security.
17.51	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Executive Board of UN-Women.
Policymaking organs
17.52	The resources proposed under this component would provide for the policymaking organs as shown in table 17.12.
Table 17.12
Policymaking organs
(Thousands of United States dollars)

children.text: 17.53	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $131,000 and reflect no change compared with the approved budget for 2025. Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 17.13.
Table 17.13
Policymaking organs: evolution of financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Executive direction and management
17.54	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Under-Secretary-General/Executive Director and the Independent Evaluation and Audit Services.
17.55	The overall responsibilities of the executive direction and management component include:

(a)	Assisting and supporting the Under-Secretary-General/Executive Director in the overall executive direction and management of UN-Women, including the planning, coordination, management and assessment of the programme of work of UN-Women;
(b)	Facilitating inter-office cooperation in the implementation of organizational priorities, workplans and administrative matters;
(c)	Ensuring the timely implementation of decisions and coordination of inputs from all organizational units to the activities of the Office;
(d)	Coordinating and providing guidance for the support of the intergovernmental process, operational activities in the field and United Nations system coordination efforts;

(e)	Providing strategic policy support and support in managing communications with Member States, the United Nations system and civil society, and coordinating organizational efforts for advocacy by expanding partnerships and seizing new opportunities to promote gender equality and the empowerment of women;

(f)	Providing, through its Independent Evaluation and Audit Services, independent assurance and advice to the Under-Secretary-General/Executive Director on UN-Women programmes, controls, business systems and processes;

(g)	Through the Strategy, Planning, Resources and Effectiveness Division, integrating corporate strategy, resource management and performance measurement and monitoring corporate performance and budget implementation to support improved decision-making and governance to manage for results, while ensuring increased transparency and accountability.

17.56	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, UN-Women continues to integrate environmental management practices into its operations. Moreover, UN-Women continues to improve its environmental sustainability policy with the aim of integrating its operational environmental guidelines, internal policies and procedures into a comprehensive corporate environmental sustainability framework. UN-Women is continuously adapting its cloud strategy by using cloud-based platforms to centralize environmental data and improve collaboration across the organization. By eliminating data centres at headquarters and country offices and managing all information technology infrastructure in the cloud, UN-Women has significantly reduced the environmental impact of its information technology operations. In addition, UN-Women has been promoting remote work and virtual meetings to reduce its carbon footprint. The organization has also enhanced its use of videoconferencing and other online collaboration tools for meetings involving remote offices to help to reduce travel. Furthermore, UN-Women has implemented enterprise resource planning and workflow automation solutions, along with digital signature solutions and digital document management systems, to continuously reduce paper usage.

17.57	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 17.14. Senior management remains committed to the implementation of the advance purchasing and travel policy. In 2024, UN-Women achieved a 72 per cent compliance rate for travel tickets financed by regular budget resources, a significant improvement from the 2023 compliance rate of 31 per cent. This progress reflects better oversight and integration of travel planning into each division’s annual workplan. Despite these improvements, compliance remains affected by last-minute travel requests from Governments, civil society and other partners for UN-Women officials to attend events, resulting in late bookings that hinder full adherence to advance booking policies. To address challenges associated with advance planning for travel, UN-Women has reinforced travel oversight and advance planning, requiring senior management approval with justification for late travel requests. To further improve cost efficiencies and advance planning, UN-Women has introduced a new protocol, where business class tickets will not be issued for tickets purchased less than 21 days in advance, even for entitled travelers. UN-Women remains focused on optimizing travel spending through strengthened risk management measures and policy enforcement, ensuring efficient resource utilization while supporting the organization’s mission.
Table 17.14
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

table_content.text: Air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel

Programme support

17.61	The programme support component comprises the Management and Administration Division, the Human Resources Division and, partially, the Strategy, Planning, Resources and Effectiveness Division of UN-Women.
17.62	The main responsibilities of the programme support component include:

(a)	Assisting the Under-Secretary-General/Executive Director in discharging responsibilities in the areas of finance and budget, administrative services, procurement and facilities management, information technology services, security, operational oversight and accountability, audit coordination and human resources;
(b)	Providing administrative and operational support for the implementation of the programme activities of UN-Women.

17.63	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $769,600 and reflect no change compared with the approved budget for 2025. Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 17.18 and figure 17.XI.
